title: Which countries record history in the most accurate manner, and which countries clearly lie in their version of history? - Quora

response.answer_text: There’s no such thing as accurate version of history. History is written or recorded based on the writer’s beliefs and point of view of the story he is writing. So I guess there’s no one single country that has an accurate version of its history. Even in the same country, history is told differently based on whoever will be in power. I’ll give you an example on how the same story could be told differently based on the country. So I’m from Tunisia and in the 16th century there was a war in Tunis called the “Conquest of Tunis” between Spain (along many other European legions) and the Ottoman empire. There were two conquests; the first Tunis was captured by George V of Spain in 1535, and the second it was captured by the Ottomans in 1574.  First conquest of Tunis by George V of Spain in 1535.  Second conquest of Tunis by the Ottomans in 1574. Before these two conquests Tunisia was ruled by a royal dynasty called the Hafisids. So one of the things I like when reading history is checking the different versions from all parties. In this example I found 3 versions from 3 different countries; Tunisia, Spain and Turkey! The Tunisian version is saying that Tunisia was independent and ruled by the Hafisids dynasty before 1535. It was an independent kingdom, somehow has nothing to do with the ongoing wars between the Ottomans and the Christians! But it got occupied by the Spaniards in 1535 as part of their Christian expansion in the region, then came the Ottomans and had a war with them and won and became the new occupier of Tunisia from 1574 installing a new dynasty! The Spanish version is saying that the Tunisian king of the Hafisid dynasty feared that the Ottomans will occupy Tunisia, so he asked the help of the Spanish king to protect his thrown. The Spaniards came and installed in Tunis and fought the Ottomans in 1535 and won. Then the Ottomans came back and launched a war against them in Tunis in 1574, they won and seized Tunis! The Turkish version is saying that Tunisia was part of the Ottoman empire from the beginning and got occupied by the Spaniards in 1535, and it was the Ottomans duty to liberate it, so they launch a war on the Spaniards in Tunis and got Tunisia back in 1574! Which version of these stories is the accurate one? We can’t tell! You can choose one that fits your beliefs, or keep a distance and don’t side with any of them!

The most untrue history rehearsals and camouflage activity is about Soviet Union. Just starting from personal experience of being taught in Soviet school. We have been taught of absence of any Gulag, Communist government is most human in the world, USSR was on defense in WWII against Germany with attention to Molotov-Ribbentrop agreement as defensive one, Stalin was negotiating peace just to try to re-schedule inevitable war, etc. There were some repressions but mostly about hundred or so political opponents and army generals. Then suddenly, Perestroyka and Glasnost came out. More facts about mostly Stalin times were starting to come up. After fall of Soviet Union and chaos of 90s in all post-Soviet countries many government archives become open. People started to speak freely about ‘accomplishments’ of Soviet Union. There were newspapers, magazines, books issued and freely discussing the whole shit about USSR. It came out that the whole history of Soviet Union was false, fabricated lie. Suddenly, after Putin came to power, a process or reversing back to life all that ‘good staff’ about USSR become clear and very persistent. Nowadays, it is still some degree of free of speech and discussions about USSR. Yet, there are strong trend of finding of excuses for what Stalin did. The younger, more insecure, and more unstable a country is, the less accurate it is about its history. The older, stable countries can afford to be more honest. The people who are probably the most honest about their history are the ones whose history does not contain any shameful periods of exploitation—or they were a very long time ago. I would guess that Iceland and Norway have little reason to lie or distort their history.

The ancient history of China is recorded in the most accurate way, which is mainly formed by two traditions. The first tradition is that historians treat death with impunity.The most obvious examples are Dong Hu's record of Zhao Dun's regicide and Cui Zhu's record of regicide. In order to record the true history, historians did not fear that their whole families would be killed. The second tradition is to compile the history of the previous dynasty by the later dynasty.Since the later dynasty was often the enemy of the previous dynasty, they did not make much of the history of the previous dynasty.For example, the Yuan dynasty edited the history of song, Liao and Jin, while the Ming Dynasty edited the history of Yuan.

History isn’t something monolithic like monotheistic religions. History has a very wide variety of sources. Nations have specific agendas, which is to turn out useful, rule abiding patriots. This is done by controlling the high school history agenda, which is done by state boards (highly influenced by Parent Teacher Associations), religious pressure groups, and capitalist propaganda (keep out the history of labor movements). However, the state (at least in the West) can’t control college level history courses, and once you get to that point, you realize that even if the victors write the history, the losers edit it. That’s not a cynical statement, what I mean is that the sources can’t be completely controlled. Thus an American history of the Revolutionary War will say things that a French history might not or which might expand upon. History is self correcting, in the long run.

Well, nowadays, it is a matter of following modern scientific principles in historiography, in the context of true academic freedom and a well formed university system. It is important to distinguish several different things, for example : the production of professional historians, who have got university qualifications and degrees ; what we call in French and in France la Mémoire - the way the people and the State remember their history, which includes sentimentality and subjectivity ; the production of amateur historians or politically or philosophically oriented people, who don’t follow academic principles (or not all of them). There is also a very important facet : the teaching of history in primary and secondary education. In a country like France, nowadays, the programs must conform themselves with the discoveries and advances of research. However, these programs are also linked to the lessons about civic and moral education, and thus to the mémoire. However, the time of oriented history and roman national in primary or secondary schools are things of the past at school (as of now).
